content: (placeholder)
Agenda: https://hackmd.io/@camelid/HyFl7C4ed
Feel free to add to the agenda!
@WG-rustc-dev-guide the meeting is starting in 54 minutes
I'll be there :)
was taking a look at the agenda
remember to add topics if you want to discuss them
I've already added some stuff
@WG-rustc-dev-guide :wave:
Agenda: https://hackmd.io/@camelid/HyFl7C4ed, thanks Camelid
Let's start with status updates

• Iñaki's work on reorganizing?
    • Aki: haven't made much progress but expect to close the initial scoped tasks (part-N renaming + redirects) this week.
@Iñaki Garay do you have something to comment?
no changes yet. still pretty sure I'll have it this week
cool
got distracted by the broken glossary
next ...

• Camelid's work on the date-checker (PR#1037)
    • Almost done, may need a bit more work and then should be mergeable
@Camelid doesn't seem to be around
let's move on

• Santiago is just back to work from vacations :beach_with_umbrella:
    • Up to take some work
    • We've discussed in the past about a walkthrough section and we wanted to get output of the different phases of the compiler. I even promised to go and check how to get something from AST if I recall correctly. We've also said that RLS does good job there. Should I go over this maybe?
  • Joshua has been on break and does not have much to report
both @Joshua Nelson and me on vacations :)
I'm just mentioning that I'm up to take some work but we can discuss that afterwards
let's get then in the first topic

• Discuss a strategy to tackle large work projects
    • Sprint with groups?
I'm +1 for sprints
so ... in the past we did sprints where we worked all together in a "big" project
and I think that worked pretty well
of course that doesn't go against somebody doing something by themselve
This is what I'm hoping for.
Working together
yeah
:+1:
Shall we discuss dates and potential topics?
it seems like most of us agree on that then

rylev said:

Shall we discuss dates and potential topics?

yeah, the agenda have a couple of big projects
but maybe it's also time to throw some more?
well I'm lying :)
in the agenda in particular there's just the layout of the agenda
which probably do not qualify as a big project
the other part is what I mentioned on my status update, the walkthrough section
That could be nice
but I think it may be a good idea to stop for a while with what there's in the agenda and do what @rylev said

rylev said:

Shall we discuss dates and potential topics?

:point_up:

I'd like to suggest doing some issue triage, I've gone over them all and there are some old ones which are almost done and could either be closed by creating a more focused (& easier) issue, and there are some "large" issues which would benefit from breaking down.
But these are things which I don't think should be done by one person alone
@Iñaki Garay are you suggesting that as a way to pick a large project or just proposing a general issue triage effort?
the second, general issue triage effort. perhaps its not enough to be considered a large effort, just one or two meetings should be enough
yeah issue triaging in general is a good thing
Yes issue triaging does seem good. I also think an effort of going through the guide and making sure that we are tracking all the todos in issues
but I'm always a bit more inclined to use whatever is in the issue tracker as input, use also our own knowledge to just try to do whatever is better for the guide

rylev said:

Yes issue triaging does seem good. I also think an effort of going through the guide and making sure that we are tracking all the todos in issues

yeah, agreed too
my main question is ... would going over all the todos and issues give us the most important things to work in the guide?
I'm a bit more inclined to use that as input and then decide what's the thing that's more important
perhaps partially, but you need to know the inventory to prioritize?
we had a projects page on github too, unsure if all that is reflected on issues
also we have some ideas I think :)
maybe what I'm saying is ... is the issue tracker complete?
one of the things I consider important is a walkthrough section
and that probably doesn't exist in the issue tracker
I think missing from the issue tracker are the todo's @rylev mentioned
and the walkthrough, yeah
anyway, not opposed :)

Given that the dev guide isn't something people tend to work on too often and tend rather to be something you dip into when you have a free moment, I can imagine the issue tracker is not in a complete state.
right
in my opinion going over all the issues may be a huge effort
and probably the guide itself if you read it shouts you for certain kind of content :)
and also, the issue tracker would never have something more high level, like I consider the guide should be written in an entire different way
I think we should focus on expanding and reorganizing the guide before issue triage
so these kind of more strategic things are not in the issue tracker
we can have a basic idea of the large tasks without having to go through each issue
exactly what @Joshua Nelson is saying :)
in my opinion trying to make a great layout for the guide, maybe reorganizing it a bit more

and having a walkthrough section, with an example where we show some code and we show what happens on each stage and stuff like that but less theoretical and more practical would be very big projects :)
and some projects that I think are the most benefitials
but in any case, I guess we should just discuss that, what would be the most benefitial big project for the guide
I like the idea of working together on a walkthrough section
One more complicated idea I'd love to do, is user testing the dev guide with new comers to the compiler
Sitting with people and understanding where they get stuck
big plus one, I've been doing this a little informally with Lokathor
that's how I found https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/76653
Although I'm not a newcomer to the guide, I haven't contributed code to rustc yet, and I'm up for being mentored on an issue, and have time

@rylev when you say get stuck, you mean with building the compiler and such, right? once you get past building there's so many different places you could be looking I'm not sure one person could be representative
I did mean primarily about building, but I do think we can still learn from people about the more theoretical parts of the guide
Of course people will have different backgrounds and expertise, but it's good to get newbies to read our technical writing
I know from experience that some parts of the guide seem to assume some background knowledge which is not well established beforehand
right both things seem like a good idea
and I guess we could do both things in parallel maybe?
like having us as a group working on the walkthrough section and trying to mentor new people to get input from them?
or were you suggesting something different?
we have 4 more minutes :)
I'm not sure about doing both in parallel. I'd leave that to the group to decide
But I'd like to see both happen soon (even if they don't happen at the same time)
right, agreed
should we decide on something before the meeting ends?
or should we schedule a new meeting for next week maybe meanwhile we think about all this?
Yes. Let's do the walk through first
(Feel free to disagree, just trying to pick a direction and run with it)
agreed on trying to pick a direction :)
about the walkthrough section, how should we get started?
I guess we can have a meeting specifically to plan about that
I'm fine with that
let's define that async
I guess we can finish this meeting, but maybe 30 minutes every 3 weeks is not enough :)
anyway, let's continue async :wave:
Sorry I missed the meeting! I had a really busy day yesterday and totally forgot about it. I'll read the messages and be sure to remember next time :)
